title: How catching waves is 'just bloody awesome' in changing people's lives
text:
Max Forster-Ross can't get enough of surfing.

"It's just bloody awesome," he said.

Mr Forster-Ross began participating in a unique surf program in Albany on Western Australia's south coast a year and a half ago.

Bringing together both surfers who are participants in the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) and non-NDIS surfers, the inclusive school is a place where participants can hone their skills together and build community.

Max Forster-Ross rides a wave to the shore. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Now, Mr Forster-Ross hits the waves three times a week with his new crew.

"[It] gets me out of the house; I don't game as much," he said.

"[It's been] awesome, people to talk to, people to hang out with, I bloody know half of Albany now.

"I feel like I'm just a different person. I know I'm not that old, but I feel young again."

Participants pop up on a "party wave". (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Sascha de Lacy-Koenig, who started Sacha's Surf Experience, spends most of his waking hours in a wetsuit running the two intertwining surf programs.

"One is our NDIS surf program where we help people achieve their life goals using surfing as a tool," he said.

"When you're surfing, you're making a lot of decisions; you're deciding which waves you should go on, you're deciding which board you should use."

He encourages participants to apply the goal-setting and decision-making they learn in the waves to other areas of their lives, from daily tasks to pursuing bigger goals.

Sascha de Lacy-Koenig wanted to share the therapeutic benefits of surfing with others. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Surfers who are part of the NDIS program also meet up with the open surf stream, which anyone can join.

"The most fun thing we get to do is bring both those groups together and have a fun time in the ocean," Mr de Lacy-Koenig said.

"It doesn't matter what your background is; if you enjoy the ocean and you love seeing these waves come through and riding them, you can connect with others in that space."

Surfing helps clear the mind. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Learning to surf 'transformative'

It's this broad community that keeps Monique Blaikie showing up rain, hail or shine.

"Even if the conditions are average, we're all still going to go out because I know there's a friend out there, or I know there's someone out there who's going to cheer me on, or encourage me, or make me feel good," she said.

Her experience over the past year has been transformative.

Monique Blaikie loves to surf at the beaches around Albany. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

"Before I started surfing, drowning was my big fear," she said.

"I wouldn't go out past waist deep. I was scared of the waves, I was very afraid of the water.

" I would call myself an ocean person now, that's part of my personality, and how I would define myself, which is completely different to who I was two years ago. "

Riley Coffey has become a mentor for some of the younger surfers. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

Riley Coffey joined the program to learn to surf with his son and has become a mentor to some of the NDIS participants.

He hopes surfing will offer them something positive as they step into new stages of life.

"It's such a nice thing, and I feel it's something that you can hold forever," Mr Coffey said.

"Compared to footy and cricket — which I grew up playing — they start getting a lot more competitive as you get older, whereas [surfing] you go at your own pace and there's no expectation, it's just enjoyment, which I find really great."

Participants surf a wave near Albany. (ABC News: Samantha Goerling)

title: 'Bit of a mystery': Darwin lord mayor's donations disclosure goes missing
text:
The Northern Territory Electoral Commission (NTEC) is investigating the campaign donations disclosure of Darwin's lord mayor, following his claim an envelope containing the information has been lost.

Former NT deputy chief minister Peter Styles was elected Darwin Lord Mayor in August and was meant to reveal his campaign donors to the NTEC by the start of November.

But the NTEC has said it did not receive Mr Styles's donor information until Tuesday this week, four days after the ABC sent questions to the lord mayor about why it had not been lodged.

Asked why he had lodged his return three months late, Mr Styles said he had actually provided a physical envelope containing his donation information to the NTEC's Darwin office on October 27.

He claimed it was then lost by the electoral commission.

The NT local government elections were held in August of 2025, with Peter Styles voted in as Darwin's Lord Mayor. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

"So that's a bit of a mystery, really," he told ABC Radio Darwin.

"I dropped an envelope in there with my [donation] returns in it at the end of October and [the NTEC] don't seem to have recorded that somewhere.

"So I don't know what's happened to it."

Mr Styles said he physically dropped off the envelope "to make sure it got there".

"Electronic things can go missing from time to time and can be deleted," he said.

"I made sure that it was actually delivered, personally delivered.

"I fulfilled my obligation and I've since sent them the information again."

Peter Styles says he fulfilled his obligation when he provided the NT Electoral Commission with a physical copy of his donations information. (ABC News: Marcus Kennedy)

Mr Styles said he was only aware that his donation information had not been recorded by the NTEC when the ABC sent him questions last Friday.

"The ABC did enquire about it, which raised the issue that it's not there," he said.

"So, I actually contacted [the NTEC] to find out what's going on and I've since given them an electronic copy this time."

NTEC investigating envelope drop-off

NT Electoral Commissioner Kirsten Kelly said the NTEC was investigating the matter and so far, it had found no information to confirm Mr Styles physically provided the envelope in October.

"But the NT Electoral Commission is working with Mr Styles and his campaign manager to work through to substantiate if it was provided [in October] and how we can demonstrate that," she told ABC Radio Darwin.

Kirsten Kelly says it is unlikely the electoral commission would issue Peter Styles with a penalty. (ABC News: Tiffany Parker)

"We'll continue to work with Mr Styles and his campaign manager just to determine dates and times and who was spoken to and work with the staff in the [NTEC] office."

Ms Kelly said it was unlikely a penalty would be issued to Mr Styles.

"At the moment we're just looking to publish those returns and continue those discussions to see if we can confirm the date of the return and that's really important," she said.

Mr Styles's disclosure was uploaded to the NTEC website on Friday afternoon, showing he received $11,000 in total from three donors.

Those donors were Thomas Lewis, Sunny The and the owner of the NT Oriental Emporium and Asia-United Food Service, Kivi Lay.

title: PM and SA premier announce $800m deal for 17,000 new homes
text:
About 17,000 new homes have been promised in an $800 million partnership between the South Australian and federal governments.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, alongside Premier Peter Malinauskas, announced the deal this morning, and said nearly 7,000 of those homes would be allocated to first-home buyers.

Mr Malinauskas said a focus of the project was to build new homes as fast as possible.

"The only way we can take on this challenge is to unlock supply and do it quickly — and what this program is all about isn't just about building more homes but getting on with it and doing it quickly," Mr Malinauskas said.

The deal focuses on development in Adelaide's north. (ABC News: Brant Cumming)

Housing affordability is set to be a major issue in March's state election, with the median house price in Adelaide reaching close to $1 million and an interest rate rise predicted on Tuesday.

Some housing estates in Adelaide's north have been built and sold to home owners before water and sewerage infrastructure has been installed, while other land releases have been announced without plans for water to be delivered for several years into the future.

Model for other states

The prime minister said the announcement was part of federal Labor's 2025 election commitment to build 100,000 homes for first-home buyers nationally.

Mr Albanese said today's commitment would act as a model for other states.

"During the election campaign we announced that it will be a model for a national scheme and that's what we're doing today," Mr Albanese said.

"This is an agreement worth more than $800 million partnering with the South Australian government."

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and South Australian Peter Malinauskas in Adelaide's north today. (ABC News: Lincoln Rothall)

The federal government will loan the state government $534 million, including $300 million for water infrastructure in Adelaide's northern suburbs and $184 million to deliver 1,700 homes at urban renewal projects around Adelaide.

The state government will match $134 million in federal funding for 750 houses for first-home buyers.

Family grateful for help

The prime minister and premier made the announcement at John Tramontano's family's home in the northern Adelaide suburb of Munno Para.

Mr Tromantono said he was only able to buy the house with help from first-home buyer schemes.

"Without those, we would not be standing at our house today, so I'm really grateful, and I think our family is too, to finally have our own home," he said.

"It's something I thought i would never achieve, to be honest, and yet here we are."

The state opposition says stamp duty and payroll tax need to be cut. (ABC News: Lincoln Rothall)

A housing industry group welcomed the announcement.

"This investment is critical to build more homes faster," Housing Industry Association managing director Jocelyn Martin said.

"Builders often tell us that getting this key 'last-mile' infrastructure is what holds many projects back from being delivered in a more timely fashion."

But opposition spokesperson Ben Hood said a shortage in construction materials and construction workers would lead to the housing promises being broken.

"South Australians know that Peter Malinauskas loves an announcement but he doesn't focus on delivery," Mr Hood said.

He said a Liberal promise to remove stamp duty on all first-home purchases up to $1 million would make a bigger difference, along with increasing the payroll tax threshold and exempting trainees and apprentices from the tax.

title: Island to get childcare solution, too late for the Archers
text:
Home to around 1,000 Tasmanians, Bruny Island has seen parents spend years advocating for local access to early childhood education, without success.

Mother-of-four Teisha Archer is one of those.

She described hearing the news this week that a breakthrough had been found as "wonderful" for the community.

"We very much welcome the announcement," she said.

" I'm getting lots and lots of messages of like, yay, finally, it's happening. "

$3.5 million has been allocated to build the centre on the site of Bruny Island District School, providing places for up to 20 children.

The federal and state governments made the announcement yesterday as part of a joint funding deal to improve access to early childhood education services, especially in regional communities.

Other communities set to receive new early learning services include Westbury, Rosetta, St Mary's, Bothwell and Huonville.

Do you live in an out-of-school care desert? In large parts of Australia, accessing a spot at before and after-school care is not an option for many parents.

The six centres will be delivered under a joint funding agreement, including $25.5 million from the federal government's Building Early Education Fund, alongside a $5 million contribution and land from the Tasmanian government.

In a joint statement, Tasmanian Minister for Education Jo Palmer said: "We know that quality early learning gives children the best possible start in life and the Tasmanian Government is delivering for our youngest learners on this lifelong journey.

"This joint investment is an exciting opportunity for these regions which we know are lacking access to ECEC services.

" We are proud to be partnering with the Commonwealth to deliver for Tasmanian families. "

Federal Minister for Education Jason Clare said: "The Building Early Education Fund will help deliver more quality early education places for families in communities that need them most.

"Where you grow up shouldn't determine whether you can access early education.

" These projects in Tasmania mean more families can access early learning close to home and more children start school ready to go and ready to learn. "

'It's been a long time coming'

Teisha Archer's youngest children will be too old to benefit from the centre by the time it opens. (ABC News: Georgie Burgess)

Ms Archer had been meeting with the education department since 2023, when it was announced that Bruny Island had been selected as a location to trial three-year-old kinder; something that failed to eventuate.

Promised early learning trial behind schedule Parents in this island community, which has no child care services, were "very excited" when an early learning trial for three-year-olds was promised by 2024.

After numerous delays and seemingly dead ends with the state government getting the program up and running, Ms Archer said the community reached a "compromise" last year, with the introduction of adjunct care, but now even that was at risk.

The adjunct care program allows toddlers and preschoolers to be dropped off at a school-based care environment on the condition their parents do not leave the premises.

"What we would do is go into another room as parents and do whatever we wanted to do for that hour, study or work or chat or whatever," Ms Archer said.

Last year, the service ran three days a week, including one full day.

It offered a temporary solution to parents on the island seeking needed breaks from their children, one that was much "appreciated" by everyone despite its limitations, according to Ms Archer.

However, the service is being reduced this year.

"We received a notification from the department saying that the adjunct care service would be cut by 5.5 hours per week," she said.

This year, it is only returning for two days, both of which will be half days.

For some parents, like Ms Archer, the timing of the cuts has raised questions about the government's broader messaging on early childhood services.

"It seems a little counterintuitive that on one hand, we've got the premier announcing the importance of early childhood services," she said.

" And then we're also seeing what our community feel is a diminishment of that offering as part of this program we're currently operating in. "

While the adjunct care program has offered some relief, parents say it falls well short of what families on Bruny Island actually need, as it makes it difficult to participate in farm work or run businesses that can not be done from home when parents are required to stay on school grounds.

"It also doesn't allow you to go off-island without the kids for basic things like shopping," said Ms Archer.

"And it becomes a really gender-loaded decision, because a lot of men who live and work on the island work physically within the environment, so they can't take their kids to adjunct care […] so what you see is all mums."

Even with a permanent childcare centre now announced, families say the timing remains a major concern.

The federal government said the Bruny Island childcare centre was not expected to open until late 2027 at the earliest, by which time Ms Archer's youngest children would already be at school full-time.

However, significant questions remain about how parents will manage in the years before the centre opens.

title: Kakadu National Park airport to be shut and demolished, raising alarm
text:
The main airport servicing the Northern Territory's Kakadu National Park has been earmarked for closure and demolition later this year, with local businesses and leaders raising the alarm for the region.

The Jabiru Airport is part of the lease area for Rio Tinto's Ranger uranium mine, which ceased operations in 2021 and is currently in the process of being rehabilitated.

Under federal regulations around the closure, the company is required to close and bulldoze the airport, which a spokesperson confirmed was its intention from October this year.

As well as the popular national park, the airport serves the nearby town of Jabiru and numerous remote Aboriginal communities in the area.

With its famous crocodile-shaped hotel, Jabiru is a gateway to Kakadu National Park. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

In a statement, Labor opposition frontbencher and Arafura MLA Manuel Brown, whose electorate covers Jabiru, said there were "serious concerns" about the "devastating consequences [the airport's] loss will bring".

"Jabiru Airport is essential for healthcare access, emergency services, employment, tourism and connection to the rest of the territory," he said.

" That is not an acceptable outcome in any part of the Northern Territory. "

At the last census in 2021, there were 755 residents in Jabiru, and 315 in the surrounding national park, while the nearby Aboriginal community of Gunbalanya had 1,177.

Manuel Brown says Gunbalanya is particularly reliant on Jabiru Airport due to road closures forced annually by the wet season. (ABC News: Ian Redfearn)

Mr Brown said he had spoken with stakeholders, including the West Arnhem Regional Council, the Northern Land Council, Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation and multiple tourism operators "who are united in their alarm about the ripple effects the airport's closure will have on the region".

He said Gunbalanya and its surrounding homeland communities were particularly reliant on Jabiru Airport due to road closures forced annually by the wet season.

Large parts of the Arnhem Land community of Gunbalanya end up under water during heavy rain. (Supplied)

"If Jabiru Airport is lost, and with it the services that support it, Gunbalanya, a community cut off by road for at least six months of the year, will be seriously impacted," he said.

" Without reliable air access, there will be no guaranteed supply of food, no timely access to medical treatment, and no emergency evacuation capability. "

'The end of Jabiru'

Charter air operator Kakadu Air is among the businesses impacted by the impending demolition.

The company's logistics manager, Mat Jones, said he believed the closure of the airport would have a dire impact on Jabiru and the surrounding West Arnhem Land.

He said the town would struggle to get food and medical supplies in during the wet season.

Kakadu Air staff have been told the gates of the airport will be locked from October. (Supplied: Kakadu Air)

"If there's no airstrip there, pretty much it will be the end of Jabiru," he said.

"We've been told that from October, the gates [of the airport] will be locked and no-one will be able to get in or out.

" It's at the point now where we think it's been left too late. "

Jabiru has also recently been struggling with its power supply, with rolling blackouts affecting the township in early January due to faults in its power station's generators.

In a statement, a Rio Tinto spokesperson said "[we] acknowledge and respect the views of all stakeholders to keep Jabiru Airport open".

Jabiru and its surrounds are home to about 1,000 people, with another 1,177 residing in the nearby community of Gunbalanya. (ABC News: Roxanne Fitzgerald)

"[We] are supportive of efforts to retain the airport subject to appropriate arrangements being agreed," they said.

If no third-party operator is found to keep the airport open, Rio Tinto is required by legislation to decommission and demolish the airport by late 2026.

Nature has long warned us about rising sea levels In wet season, Jonathan and his family have to drive, boat and drive again if they want to reach town. The remote NT traditional owner says nature has long been warning us about climate change.

Mr Brown called on the NT's Country Liberal Party government and the Commonwealth to "find a permanent solution to keep Jabiru Airport operational, not just a short-term bandaid solution".

"The people of Jabiru and West Arnhem deserve clear answers and a firm decision now," he said.

A spokesperson for Resources and Northern Australia Minister Madeleine King said: "The Commonwealth remains in discussions with the NT government and other stakeholders on the future status of the airport as a matter of priority to provide certainty for traditional owners, local communities and businesses."

NT Housing, Local Government and Community Development Minister Steve Edgington said the government was "working with the Commonwealth and key stakeholders to come to a resolution".

title: Growers turn to netting to save crops from heatwave sunburn
text:
Humans are told to slip, slop, slap, seek and slide, but for agricultural crops, seeking shade has never been more important.

The latest heatwave that gripped the south-east of the country broke temperature records, with highs above 49 degrees Celsius in New South Wales and South Australia.

But the extreme temperatures have raised questions in key fruit-growing regions about how to protect crops and businesses from heat in the future.

Craig Burne says sustained hot days either side of a heatwave are a problem. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

For persimmon and avocado grower Craig Burne in South Australia's Riverland, netting infrastructure across his persimmon crop has been a lifeline.

"We have overhead misting systems that come on at 35 degrees to help cool the avocado orchard ... and we have our nets for the persimmons," he said.

"Without these two systems in place, I don't think we'd successfully grow either of these crops in this climate anymore.

Craig Burne says it will take days until he knows the full extent of his avocado crop loss. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

" I think [netting] is going to be absolutely mandatory for many crops to survive the heat. "

Mr Burne said while some of his persimmon crop was heat-affected, it held up better than his avocado crops, which were not covered by netting.

Fruit exposed to the sun can quickly become sunburnt and turn brown. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

"Without those net structures protecting fruit from that sun and those extreme heat events, you're not going to get through without crop loss, it's as simple as that," he said.

Netting the way of the future?

G2 Netting Group sales director Kyle Lamont said netting sales across Australia had increased in recent years, especially in regions including the Riverland, Sunraysia and Goulburn Valley.

"Over the last five to 10 years, there's definitely been an uptake and an increase in growers looking for protection," he said.

Kyle Lamont says some netting structures can reduce UV exposure by up to 20 per cent. (Supplied: Kyle Lamont)

"There's really no growing regions that aren't increasing netting structures.

"[Growers] can maintain a more stable environment under the netting structures, and during the peak of those heatwaves, it's probably 2 or 3 degrees cooler under those structures."

Mr Lamont said export markets in countries such as China, Korea and Japan were only accepting "pristine" fruit, highlighting the need for sun protection.

"People buy with their eyes, so unfortunately, that means [growers] have to produce blemish-free fruit, and that's getting harder with these extreme challenges from Mother Nature," he said.

Mr Lamont said some netting structures could cost about $60,000 per hectare to install.

Netting infrastructure usually has a lifespan of around 15 years. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

Mr Lamont said while he believed there was still a place for small fruit producers who were unable to afford netting, it was a no-brainer for corporate growers to install the infrastructure.

"Netting is an insurance policy, and I believe most large-scale or major growers will be going that way," he said.

South Australia's Department of Primary Industries and Regions previously offered grants of up to 50 per cent on netting infrastructure installation or repairs for Riverland and Adelaide Hills growers.

The funding stream ended on June 30, 2025.

Hotter days and longer heatwaves

Adelaide University environmental health researcher Peng Bi said heatwaves would continue to be an issue across the country.

"We are seeing the increase of heatwaves across Australia. In Adelaide [for example], heatwaves occurred in 2009, 2014, 2019, 2024, and now 2026, so there are a lot of heatwaves happening," he said.

Peng Bi says inland regions are likely to be affected by heatwaves more than coastal regions. (ABC News: Brant Cumming)

"Those intense heatwaves have and will continue to impact society, including productivities from agricultural areas."

Professor Bi said mitigation and adaptation to climate change would be crucial.

"[Heatwaves] will affect the population's health, and it will likely impact farming communities and their outdoor activities, for example," he said.

Craig Burne says despite the harsh conditions, he will continue to grow fruit into the future. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

Back in the state's Riverland, Mr Burne said consolidating his crop varieties may be the way forward.

"The question will be, do we start consolidating our business in terms of moving away some of the avocado orchards that aren't as productive ... and replant to persimmons to remain under net?" he said.

"In an ideal situation, I'd have my whole farm under net, but avocados are just too damn big to grow under nets."

title: Ballroom community takes over Australia's oldest library
text:
A dozen performers donning angelic white and crimson outfits dance along a runway to thunderous applause from the crowd and chants of "Hey hey what's up, Furia f*** it up!"

This is not a conventional Saturday night for the State Library Victoria.

Normally a space of quiet reading, the 172-year-old institution was transformed into the Fantasy Ball, a queer pageant-like event where attendees from across the country come to watch participants "walk" in eight categories.

Loading...

Ballroom is a burgeoning subculture with roots in late 20th-century Harlem, New York, created to foster community and safety for LGBTQIA+ people of colour, particularly trans women.

The subject of the 1990 documentary Paris is Burning and the hit drama series Pose, ballroom has since found its way to Australian cities.

Founding mother of the House of Furia, Angel, says the Fantasy Ball is about allowing queer people to live out their dreams. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

Fantasy Ball curator Angel Furia says ballroom provided a space for queer people living on the margins to experience their fantasy.

"In ballroom, the fantasy of walking a category is usually walking a category that does not exist in your everyday life," Angel says.

" The fantasy is creating that visual representation of yourself. It's almost like manifesting for yourself who you can be. "

'Vogue fem'

In the beginners' performance category, participants dressed as fairies fly down the runway performing "vogue fem", a high-energy dance characterised by fluid, feminine movement.

Vogue fem is a dance style integral to ballroom, with five elements including duck walks and dips. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

Competitors weave their arms in flamboyant patterns, and synchronise their dips to drops in the backing music, while a quick-witted commentator stirs up the crowd.

Solana Iman was living "every fantasy" after winning the beginner's performance category. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

After a few rounds of eliminations, a battle ensues between the final two fairies, with Solana Iman declared the victor.

"For me, voguing is an expression, it's a feeling, it's not just a dance move. It's a struggle that queer POC [people of colour] have to go through," she tells the ABC.

Takudzwa 007 vogues the house down in the beginners' performance category. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

Runner-up Takudzwa 007 says voguing is the "main attraction" of ballroom for him.

"A lot of it has an element to it that expresses the feminine in such a raw way for me," he says.

"It just feels like that side of my queer identity can be fully out there."

Chosen family

Within ballroom, participants compete as individuals, known as 007s, or as a member of a collective, known as a house.

The house often serves as a "chosen family", a support system for community members who may struggle to connect with their biological family.

Experienced members nurture younger talent.

Ballroom houses give queer people a chosen family, with house mothers nurturing their children. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

"Chosen family is really important for me because they've been there for me during my ups and downs," Solana says.

"I grew up in a conservative Muslim black family household, so they're not really accepting."

" When I found ballroom, that's when I found family and who I was as a person. "

House of Furia opens the ball with a grand march, showcasing sharp dance skills and impeccable fashion. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

The category is …

The categories demand an intimate knowledge of ballroom, sharp performance skills, and the right dose of artistic flair.

Performers are judged by a panel of seasoned judges, with the goal of achieving a perfect score or "10s across the board".

The Bizarre x Best Dressed category calls for an effect inspired by a deity from your ancestry. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

Judge Chantal 007 Revlon says she looks for performers who are "fearless".

"I'm looking for you to be audacious, and I'm looking for you to tell me your story," she says.

Chantal 007 Revlon sits on the judging panel and says ballroom is a safe space, and a brave space. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

"I want you to be able to bring me into your world, like this is your world and I'm just living in it.

LGBTQI+ community support services ABCQueer has compiled this list of national and state-based support services relevant to LGBTQI+ people, their families and friends.

"Ballroom is sometimes a safe space, but it's mostly a brave space, and it's a space where you are required to be fearless and believe in yourself."

But if you fail to meet the requirements of the category, you face being chopped.

For the femme queens

Throughout the evening, commentators remind the audience that the event is about celebrating "femme queens", ballroom terminology for trans women.

Lilo 007 puts on a fierce showing in the Victoria's Secret inspired European Runway category. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

"A femme queen is a woman who owns her power no matter what," Heidi Furia said.

Once an online streamer, Heidi was encouraged by one of her viewers to explore the ballroom scene.

Eventually, it led her to being welcomed into a community of trans women.

Winner, winner: Mother Leah Iman's house triumphs in four categories. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

"I met those women for the first time in my life, but it really felt like I knew them for so many years," she says.

" It felt really nice to be around people who are just like me. "

Stepping onto the stage with her house, Heidi says she is living her dream.

"Ballroom is so important because in this climate, this is where our queer youth need to be celebrated, understood, accepted and lifted up," Heidi said.

Cyrus Iman takes Kylie Minogue 'Padam Padam' red to new heights in the European Runway category. (ABC News: Jacob Gamble)

"We need to be able to feel like we can conquer this world just as much as anyone else."

title: Sabalenka the favourite but Rybakina pledges 'fight to the end'
text:
Aryna Sabalenka will bid for a third Australian Open trophy in four years when the Belarusian collides with fellow power-hitter Elena Rybakina in a heavyweight rematch of their title showdown three years ago.

The dynamics have shifted since Sabalenka's breakthrough win in 2023, the 27-year-old now the clear favourite following three more Grand Slam triumphs and Rybakina yet to win another major after her 2022 Wimbledon success.

Djokovic hits out at critics Novak Djokovic sets his sights on those who doubted whether he could still be an Australian Open contender.

The pair know each other well, having met 14 times on tour, with Sabalenka holding a narrow edge in a rivalry marked by bruising baseline battles and momentum swings.

But the top seed said history would count for little on Rod Laver Arena.

"We both are different players," Sabalenka said.

"We went through different things and we're much stronger mental and physically. We're playing better tennis now. So I'll approach this as completely different match.

"We have long history after that final. I'll approach this match as the very first one and I will do my very best."

Victory would give Sabalenka her fifth Grand Slam title, drawing her level with Martina Hingis and Maria Sharapova and cementing her place among the most successful players of the modern era.

Aryna Sabalenka can make it three Australian Open titles in four years. (Getty Images: Clive Brunskill)

Russian-born Kazakh Rybakina holds the recent bragging rights, having defeated Sabalenka in the WTA Finals title match at the end of 2025.

The fifth seed said she was banking on that experience to get her over the line at Melbourne Park.

"Of course, many years have passed and a lot of matches have been played," Rybakina said.

"Hopefully all the experience I got from the last match, and the last final that I played here, I can bring it to Saturday's match and do my best.

"Since we're both very aggressive players the serve will be important. I'll fight till the end, and hopefully this time it's going to go my way."

But the 2023 AO final between the pair, in which Sabalenka fought back from a set down to claim the first of her four major crowns so far, stands out.

"It was very close. Throughout the match, of course, I had some little opportunities but in the end of this third set I think Aryna stepped in," Rybakina said.

"She served much better. Yeah, she deserved that win."

Elena Rybakina is hoping to win her second grand slam title. (Getty Images: Fred Lee)

Melbourne has been especially kind to Sabalenka.

She has won 26 of her last 27 matches at the year's first Grand Slam with her only defeat coming against Madison Keys in the 2025 final, which denied her a Melbourne Park "three-peat".

Australian Open day 13 quick hits Gadecki and Peers make their own bit of history and "old man" Djokovic turns back the clock to reach his 11th Aussie final. Here are the quick hits from day 13 at the Australian Open.

Sabalenka's game is tailor-made for the fast, blue hardcourts which have rewarded her heavy first serve and flat groundstrokes, and she has not dropped a set en route to the final this year.

Rybakina has been just as efficient, marking the first time that both Australian Open women's finalists have reached the decider without surrendering a set since Justine Henin and Kim Clijsters in 2004.

While Sabalenka breezed past Elina Svitolina 6-2, 6-3 in the semi-finals, Rybakina had to battle against Jessica Pegula to earn a 6-3, 7-6(9/7) win and keep her record intact.

The 2022 All England Club champion has been in blistering form since the latter stages of last year, piecing together 13 wins from her last 14 matches and sustaining a level of consistency that has made her a threat.

Wires

title: Parental estrangement isn't new but social media makes it harder
text:
A mere 2,000 years after the disciple Luke taught us about the Prodigal Son, social media has finally discovered the concept of "going no contact" with your parents.

Unusually, Oprah got there a little later than everybody else who had already been mass-posting about quitting toxic relatives, when she broadcast a blockbuster YouTube show featuring abandoned parents and rejecting children over this "new" trend — she called it — of cutting parents out of your lives.

A short time afterwards, Brooklyn — the first-born son of interstellar celebrities, Victoria and David Beckham — also got the memo and very publicly sacked his parents. The world has been in a kind of ecstatic, voyeuristic, schadenfreudic freefall ever since.

Oprah Winfrey broadcast a blockbuster YouTube show featuring abandoned parents and rejecting children. (AP: Paul Drinkwater)

An age-old sorrow

Back home, just a scant two years ago, high-flying PWC chief and Carlton Football Club president, Luke Sayers, was jetting to the walled Renaissance town of Lucca in Tuscany for the 50th birthday celebrations of his wife, Cate, along with enough of their close personal friends to book out almost the entire town.

Loading Instagram content

The roiling PWC tax leaks scandal was blowing up behind him as he left, and yet Sayers's magical life of expensive, luxurious celebrations appeared untouched.

Fast-forward to today and the couple are now estranged, and engaged in a defamation action involving a lewd picture, with their daughters publicly taking the side of their father against their mother.

Happy families, unhappy families — Tolstoy told you years ago how this goes. But most of that sad and sorry stuff of parents who can't connect with kids, and kids who can't trust their parents goes on in quiet desperation behind walls we never get to see through.

So, when this age-old sorrow explodes in public, it's almost reassuring, a kind of sick-making corrective when the rich and beautiful and blessed and entitled and seemingly perfect are also revealed to have car-crash lives, just like the rest of us.

There is little mystery to family breakdown. The complexity of making those intertwined, sometimes traumatised, sometimes poorly managed connections work is so dense, it is a wonder so many of these units thrive at all.

Estrangement not a new concept

A lot of us can reproduce. That biological ability is absolutely no predictor of us being able to parent. Home and family have never been safe for many many people. Walking away has a long history, as Brooklyn Beckham's similarly estranged close friends, the Sussexes, have found.

Sign up for Weekend Reads in your inbox Start your weekend with the best of the ABC's journalism, presented by Virginia Trioli. Discover compelling features, big ideas and revealing analysis to understand the stories that matter to Australians.

But it is a continuing mystery when the seemingly perfect family chooses to implode so publicly, briefs so many other conduits of their drama, and seeks so many witnesses to their pain. The final taboo — Shakespeare's serpent-toothed, ungrateful child — will always be shocking. The spectacle is an enduringly irresistible one, but after a short period of ogling it, one feels compelled to look away.

So, it's clear that while recent social media may have given it a hashtag, the phenomenon of cutting off parents perceived as unkind or damaging is as old as the concept of family itself. As Oprah found, we have many new terms for an age-old disaffection. You can lose yourself in the social-media miasma of "recognising toxic parents" or "setting boundaries".

Brooklyn Beckham recently announced he was cutting ties with his parents. (Reuters: Aude Guerrucci/File Photo)

Curiously, the therapist on Oprah's podcast who leaned towards the importance of reconciliation wanted to suggest that the more people heard such terms the more they might be led to cutting parents out of their lives (intriguingly, his daughter had done that to him for several years).

But after decades of interviewing people on my radio shows from any and all backgrounds but with complex family histories, it was always mind-blowing to me how children are wired to love and forgive their parents to an extraordinary degree.

David Beckham breaks silence after son Brooklyn cuts ties The soccer superstar tells broadcasters at the World Economic Forum that "children are allowed to make mistakes" in his first public comments since his son's allegations went public.

I spoke to adult kids of people who faced problems with gambling or drug and alcohol use, absconders, fathers who were barely there, mothers who were barely coping, and despite the sadness and the trauma they were sharing, they almost all concluded with how much they loved their parents. I heard it again and again. "I know that despite all that (insert horror here) she really loved me and I loved her."

The connection and the empathy and the need to make that primary relationship work and thrive is hard-wired into children. It takes so much to break it — so much more than many well-meaning therapists realise, I think.

It's a classic iceberg dilemma: you will only ever see the very top.

Histories with long tails

In a case like the Beckhams, we will get to see the seemingly minor absolute last straw — an apparently inappropriate mother-son dance at a wedding — but not what one of Oprah's guests called "the one thousand little things" that finally led to the decision to walk. Those histories have very long tails.

There is perhaps one very contemporary lesson in these age-old family sorrows, and that is the dangerous game of commodifying children and so perfectly packaging a family on social media and its possible consequences.

Brooklyn Beckham cut ties with his parents. Here's how it went down Celebrity family rifts are not new. Experts weigh in on how they can spark negative feelings about our own family dynamics.

Perhaps when such families, particularly the Beckhams, have built a literal brand (they trademarked their kids' names at birth) out of an image of family perfection, the rot sets in early for children who eventually chafe against it. It's a risky strategy when kids will always grow up, develop their own point of view and start to do the most ordinary but always confounding thing to their parents: they look at us and they judge us.

This weekend there is really only one thing I want to read about and understand — and only Julia Baird can help me: why are all these sharks attacking us?

Have a safe and happy weekend and let's start our year of sounds with a beautiful, yearning tune from London-born Arlo Parks, who wrote this song as an ode to the beautiful oblivion found of the dancefloor, somewhere we'll need to find ourselves a lot more this year. I feel. Nice to see you all again. Go well.

Virginia Trioli is presenter of Creative Types and a former co-host of ABC News Breakfast and Mornings on ABC Radio Melbourne.

title: Six hospitalised during seven hours of e-scooter carnage overnight
text:
Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime.

Remove items from your saved list to add more.

You have reached your maximum number of saved items.

Six people, including one primary-school-aged boy in Brisbane, were hospitalised from the Gold Coast to Townsville overnight after accidents involving e-scooters or e-bikes.

In seven hours, from 7.30pm on Friday to early Saturday morning, paramedics were called to six crashes, as well as an e-scooter fire in Kawana in which no-one was injured.

The primary-school-aged boy was taken to the Queensland Children’s Hospital with a leg injury after an “e-scooter and pedestrian incident” on South Brisbane’s Grey Street just before 10pm.

Premier David Crisafulli has promised action on e-scooters and e-bikes, but not before an inquiry delivers its report. QUT

On the Gold Coast, a teenage boy was hospitalised in a stable condition with leg injuries after falling from an e-bike at Helensvale, while another suffered head injuries after a scooter fall at Coomera.

title: Divinyls legend Chrissy Amphlett lives on in potent and moving performance
text:
Advertisement

★★★★½ CultureLive reviewsSydney live reviews Divinyls legend Chrissy Amphlett lives on in potent and moving performance John Shand January 31, 2026 — 12:05pm Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

CABARET

Amplified

Belvoir St Theatre, January 30

Until February 8

Reviewed by JOHN SHAND

★★★★½ Long after Chrissy Amphlett’s band Divinyls ground to a halt, she imagined doing a one-woman theatrical show about herself and her songs. Having spent her Divinyls career playing a fiery, racy, pouting, unpredictable schoolgirl, she wanted a character this time, too, reportedly settling on a crow. It was never to be. She died of breast cancer before the half-formed dream took flight. Enter Sheridan Harbridge, Glenn Moorhouse and Sarah Goodes. Together, they envisaged a ghost of the show Amphlett had contemplated, subtitling it The Exquisite Rock and Rage of Chrissy Amphlett. Harbridge wrote it, with Moorhouse as musical director and Goodes directing Harbridge’s performance. They’ve done a storming job. Sheridan Harbridge as Chrissy Amphlett in a potent performance. Jade Ellis Harbridge doesn’t become Chrissy, in the sense that the story is told in the third person, but Amphlett’s spirit is alive and living dangerously inside Harbridge’s performance.

Advertisement

What a range the latter has, from being the best Blanche I’ve seen in A Streetcar Named Desire, to now exploding off the stage with a singing voice I didn’t know she had, that could be brutally powerful when required, yet also sweetly soulful. Harbridge’s voice can be brutally powerful but also sweetly soulful. Jade Ellis Beyond the potency of her performance and the engaging storytelling, the music and spoken word are interwoven so that a Divinyls hit might start, shudder to a stop while Harbridge tells us more, pick up again, and repeat this process. It’s done so well that you’re not cursing the fact that they won’t get on with the song; you’re engrossed in an ever-growing tension that finally finds release when the song takes centre-stage. Sheridan Harbridge in full flight. Jade Ellis

Advertisement

Another strength is the music itself, with Moorhouse (on guitar) joined by Clarabell Limonta (keyboard), Ben Cripps (bass) and Dave Hatch (drums). I never particularly rated Divinyls as a band, compared with their songs and Amphlett’s performance of them. Moorhouse and company have knocked some bricks out of the wall of sound and replaced them with nuance, without losing the kick to the surging chorus of, say, Boys in Town. Related Article What’s on Chrissy Amphlett wrote a show in which she was a crow. Years after her death, her vision lives on The fearless Harbridge, meanwhile, doesn’t just enter the audience, she invades it. She’s also funny, and the humour makes for a completeness of emotional impact, given the inherent sadness of a story of excess, of Amphlett’s repeatedly having to smash the same glass ceiling, and then suffering multiple sclerosis before the cancer hit. Perhaps it’s also so moving because the show exudes such immense affection for its subject. If the intensity of grip is released a little in the final phase, it’s certainly reasserted when they launch into I Touch Myself, the song that made the teenage Harbridge a fan.

Advertisement

I suspect Amphlett would approve. She’d have appreciated the absence of hagiography and sugar-coating, and she may have recognised a fellow traveller in the high-stakes game of being audacious on stage. She may have even stood up with the rest of us at the end. The Booklist is a weekly newsletter for book lovers from Jason Steger. Get it delivered every Friday.

title: A Turkish favourite expands to Vic Park – and brings an exclusive doner with it
text:
Advertisement

Review Eating outVictoria Park A Turkish favourite expands to Vic Park – and brings an exclusive doner with it A doner kebab with a difference, the smoky kiss of charcoal, great breads plus an all-time baklava: just four reasons to set course for Antep Mangal’s new outpost. Max Veenhuyzen January 31, 2026 Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

1 / 7 Yaprak doner plate. Matt O'Donohue 2 / 7 Chicken shish plate. Matt O'Donohue 3 / 7 An Iskender plate being finished with tomato sauce and melted butter. Matt O'Donohue 4 / 7 Chicken pide. Matt O'Donohue 5 / 7 Adana shish plate. Matt O'Donohue 6 / 7 The fine-boned Turkish flatbread lahmacun. Matt O'Donohue 7 / 7 Walnut baklava. Matt O'Donohue Previous Slide Next Slide 14 / 20 How we score Turkish$$$$ “Daaaaad,” bleats one of the teenage boys on the table next to us. “Do they do meat boxes here?” “Of course they do meat boxes,” says Mr I-Can’t-Wait-Till-The-School-Holidays-Are-Over, somewhat shortly. As it turns out, his reply is somewhat incorrect, too. Yes, the menu at Antep Mangal Victoria Park – a shiny 40-seat Turkish takeaway that opened on New Year’s Day – features doner kebab meat, a key component of the meat box, also known as the halal snack pack or HSP. Yes, the menu also includes chips: thick, crunchy blocks of potato that are the colour of a Simpsons character.

Advertisement

But no, the menu doesn’t include an option to order both items together, or at least not in a box, drowned in sauces. Veteran chef Celal Per cutting slices of meat off a yaprak (leaf) doner. Matt O'Donohue Restaurant reviews, news and the hottest openings served to your inbox. Sign up A theory: maybe dad is a regular at the original Antep Mangal that Welat Yilmaz and Hasan Siringul opened six years ago on Beaufort Street to address the shish kebab, gozleme, pide and meat box deficiencies that the area was facing? So when news broke that Antep Mangal was expanding south, it’s a given that venue number two would offer the same menu, right? Wrong. Instead, Yilmaz and Siringul want you to consider getting your doner hit via more traditional formats. As an Iskender, perhaps: a saucy arrangement of meat, tomato sauce and melted butter, piled on flatbread and presented alongside a cooling snowdrift of tangy yoghurt. Turkey has strong historical ties to Central Asia, hence the prevalence of dairy in its cuisine. (See the house-made ayran, a mildly salted drinking yoghurt.)

Advertisement

Or maybe you could try the doner plate that invites buttery rice, unusually verdant salad plus fluffy bulgur (cracked wheat) simmered in the Turkish capsicum paste biber salcasi to the party. It’s an option that doesn’t just help you tick off your five serves of veg for the day: it also showcases the chew and eating quality of the meat itself. Look carefully at the hunk of flesh slowly gyrating on the vertical spit in the open kitchen, and you’ll spy countless strata lines throughout. This is no garden-variety doner, but a yaprak or “leaf” doner: its name a reference to the layers – or leaves – of lamb and beef that veteran chef Celal Per uses to build each towering mille-feuille of meat. Per is also on cutting duties and shaves slices off the doner in both long strips and short patches to create different mouthfeels and textures. The kicker? The yaprak is exclusive to Antep Mangal’s new Vic Park spin-off. Related Article Pop-up prodigies drop a line in Perth’s north Like the Mount Lawley mothership, all the skewers (shish) are grilled to order over compressed charcoal. Crucially, the mangal – the Turkish word for “grill” – smoulders all day, meaning char-grilled meat is available from just before lunch to early supper and any time in between. (Many grill places, perhaps understandably, only light their charcoal at night and during peak periods.) True, you’ll wait longer for your shish here than some places, but the juiciness and controlled char of finished dishes suggests that your patience isn’t going unrewarded. My pick of the shish is the adana, a succulent blend of minced beef and lamb, capsicum and spice that’s pressed by hand onto each skewer.

Advertisement

Skewers of meat being grilled over the charcoal-fuelled mangal. Matt O'Donohue In addition to being served with rice and salad, these shish can also be ordered as kebabs tucked into puffy sleeves of Turkish bread alongside red onion, diced tomato, some leafy things and nothing else. No questions about sauces. No egg upsell. No double-meat option. These are minimalist kebabs that have been deliberately designed to not just highlight the quality of the meat, but also to quietly reinforce the restaurant’s less-is-more mantra. Vic Park’s menu might not cover as much ground as Mount Lawley’s, but it takes diners closer to Turkey. That kebab bread, by the by, is one of many items made in-house. There’s also an assortment of boat-shaped pide that are either baked open-faced or sealed like a pastie depending on its filling. They’re good eating, but my picks among the baked goods are the lahmacun (thin flatbreads of impressive finesse topped with minced lamb and beef) and the excellent baklava, dense with walnuts and crowned with tanned, ruffled edges of crunchy yufka pastry. Related Article Good Food hat 15 / 20 Review This fine dining destination in the Perth Hills embodies the spirit (and flavours) of Australia Yet for all the understated detail in its cooking, Antep Mangal looks a lot like your average neighbourhood kebab joint. Diners order at a long counter. (The layout of the room occasionally causes bottlenecks if there’s a queue and staff need to deliver food to dine-in guests.) Extraction fans work valiantly to yank out all that smoke but aren’t quite strong enough. The fridge is filled with multinational soft drinks. But don’t be fooled. Beneath this unassuming exterior is a shop cooking and serving some quietly impressive Turkish food. I dig it. A lot.

Advertisement

But I also dig Turkish cuisine’s wilder, less-classical moments too, not least the restorative power of a saucy, two-handed kebab at the end of a night out. (But please don’t bring alcohol to Antep Mangal, it’s a halal restaurant.) Some might suggest that makes me a bogan. I prefer the term open-minded. This town, I think, is big enough for both styles of Turkish food. For anyone keen to think and eat outside the (meat) box, Vic Park awaits. The low-down Atmosphere: a promising second act gently expanding the public’s perception of Turkish food. Go-to dishes: adana shish kebab ($20), Yaprak doner plate ($27), lahmahcun ($10). Drinks: the Turkish salted drinking yoghurt ayran supplemented with a fridge full of multinational soft drinks (no BYO). Cost: about $65 for two people, excluding drinks. Good Food reviews are booked anonymously and paid independently. A restaurant can’t pay for a review or inclusion in the Good Food Guide.

title: Bill Gates caught STD from Russian girls, Epstein claimed
text:
Advertisement

WorldNorth AmericaEpstein fallout Bill Gates caught STD from Russian girls, Epstein claimed Gordon Rayner , Verity Bowman and Nick Gutteridge January 31, 2026 — 10:09am Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

Bill Gates caught a sexually transmitted disease after sleeping with “Russian girls”, Jeffrey Epstein claimed in files released by the US Justice Department. Epstein, who died in prison in 2019, also claimed the Microsoft founder asked for antibiotics he could “surreptitiously give” to his then-wife Melinda, from whom he is now divorced. Bill Gates’s spokesperson denied the claim as “absolutely absurd and completely false”. AP In a separate email, Epstein told Peter Mandelson he had “monstrous fun” with Gates in Seattle. Three million pages of documents released by the Trump administration also contain new photographs of Epstein with Gates.

Advertisement

The files also reveal that Epstein offered Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor dinner with a 26-year-old Russian girl, as well as a claim that Epstein gave Lord Mandelson’s husband £10,000 for an osteopathy course. Related Article Epstein fallout US Justice Department releases millions of pages of Epstein documents Seven years after his death, Epstein continues to cast a long shadow over those who were in his orbit – and Gates, once the world’s richest man, is among them. On July 18, 2013, Epstein sent a memo to himself including a number of allegations about Gates. It said: “To add insult to the injury you them [sic] implore me to please delete the emails regarding your std, your request that I provide you antibiotics that you can surreptitiously give to Melinda and the description of your penis.”

Advertisement

Epstein sent himself another email at 1.03 the same morning, announcing a resignation from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Epstein never worked for the foundation, so it is believed he was writing the email in someone else’s voice. Gates was given an honorary knighthood by Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace in 2005, in recognition of his services to charity. He was made a Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire but is not known as “Sir”, a title reserved only for British citizens. It is likely there will now be calls for the honour to be revoked, though Whitehall sources would not be drawn on whether No.10 would back such a move. A spokesman for Gates said: “These claims are absolutely absurd and completely false. “The only thing these documents demonstrate is Epstein’s frustration that he did not have an ongoing relationship with Gates, and the lengths he would go to entrap and defame.”

Advertisement

Fresh questions for Mandelson Other files raise fresh questions about the relationship between Epstein and Lord Mandelson, who was sacked as the British ambassador to Washington last year over previous revelations about his links to a man he called his “best pal”. Lord Mandelson referred to Epstein as “a good friend and totally trustworthy” in another newly released message. In a separate July 2011 email, Lord Mandelson asked Epstein, “what u doing?” Epstein replied: “Spent the day with Gates, in Seattle. Having monstrous fun.” Documents that were included in the previous batch of files. AP

Advertisement

Meanwhile, Mountbatten-Windsor will face fresh scrutiny over his own relationship with the convicted sex abuser, whose friendship led to him being stripped of his titles last year. The files show that Epstein introduced him to a 26-year-old Russian woman in 2010, after his conviction for soliciting prostitution. In emails to a contact listed as “The Duke”, Epstein wrote: “I have a friend who i think you might enjoy having dinner with, her name is irina she will be london 20-24 [sic].” In response, the former Duke of York appeared to reply: “Of course. I am in Geneva until the morning of 22nd but would be delighted to see her. Will she be bringing a message from you? Please give her my contact details to get in touch.” It was signed “HRH The Duke of York KG”. Epstein later clarified the woman was “26, Russian, clevere [sic] beautiful, trustworthy and yes she has your email”.

Advertisement

Other emails between Mountbatten-Windsor and Ghislaine Maxwell, who is currently serving a 20-year prison sentence for child trafficking, were also published on Friday. Related Article Royal family Prince Andrew photo no fake, says photographer who sourced it in 2011 The disgraced British socialite sent an email to an address linked to Mountbatten-Windsor with her condolences after the death of his grandmother in 2002. The email, sent on March 31, 2002, and addressed to “The Invisible Man”, refers to him as “sweet pea” and says of the late Queen Mother: “She was wonderful, and I am happy that I managed to meet her and speak with her.” The following day she received a reply thanking her and signed “A xxx”.

Advertisement

Todd Blanche, the deputy US attorney-general, said the material published included more than 2000 videos and 180,000 images, though not all were taken by Epstein or those close to him, and they included “large quantities of commercial pornography”. The Trump administration was required by law to release all the material it holds on Epstein, who was jailed in 2009 after admitting soliciting prostitution, by December 19 last year. It had only released a fraction of the files by the deadline. The remainder of the material is believed to have now been published. Epstein’s wide network of rich and powerful friends also included Donald Trump, who Epstein had claimed “knew about the girls”. However, Blanche insisted Trump had been exonerated by the full release of the files. He said: “In none of these communications, even when doing his best to disparage President Trump, did Epstein suggest President Trump had done anything criminal or had any inappropriate contact with any of his victims.” The Telegraph, London Get a note directly from our foreign correspondents on what’s making headlines around the world. Sign up for our weekly What in the World newsletter.

title: If a summer of sharks restores our respect for the ocean, that’s no bad thing
text:
Advertisement

NationalNSWSharks Opinion If a summer of sharks restores our respect for the ocean, that’s no bad thing Malcolm Knox Journalist, author and columnist January 31, 2026 — 9:30am

January 31, 2026 — 9:30am Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

“Going for a swim?” It had been a stinking hot day’s work, and Manly beach was metres away, but the tradie wasn’t interested. “Not a chance, not even up to my ankles.” Fear is not going in above the ankles one day, then diving straight into a rip the next. DIONNE GAIN The Manly stretch has been a sobering sight since January 19 when, in the third Sydney shark incident in barely 24 hours, a surfer was pulled from the waves at North Steyne with critical injuries. Andre de Ruyter would lose his lower leg, and the previous day at Nielsen Park in Sydney Harbour, 12-year-old Nico Antic suffered fatal injuries. Between those two events, a surfer’s board was bitten at Dee Why, not far from where, a few months earlier, Mercury Psillakis died. If we are lucky, 2025-26 will be marked out as the freak year when people in Sydney became too scared of sharks to go into the water. Gradually, they’re creeping back. No Nippers yet, but the heat has propelled a handful of swimmers into the water at South Manly. The Queenscliff ocean pool, warm with weed and wee, has been doing brisk business. In the last few days some swimmers, sticking tight and staying close to shore, have tested the open water. The patrolling jet skis and rubber duckies have eased off. Sirens, set off by electronic signals from tagged sharks, go off at their usual three or four times a week. If there were surfable waves (there haven’t been), boardriders would be edging back.

Advertisement

North Steyne was among a number of Sydney beaches closed after shark sightings and incidents in January. George Chan/Getty Images Fear isn’t meant to be logical. One headland north, normality resumed quicker at Freshwater. South of the harbour, beach life was only momentarily interrupted, as if bull sharks only knew to turn left at Sydney Heads. There has been a widespread sense of loss, as if people have had their territorial rights to their ocean summer rescinded. Warm days have heightened this feeling that an entitlement has been taken away. As one proponent of shark culling asked, “Sharks can have the whole ocean. Can’t we just have the first hundred metres?” While understandable, these sentiments are based more in emotion and habit than evidence. It hasn’t taken long for humans to get used to the idea that they own this fringe of littoral water, and that sharks, like those other beach infringers, the cabana builders, have violated their free space. I’m not saying that selfish cabana people are any smarter than sharks, but regulation and negotiation can at least modify their behaviour. Sharks tend not to listen to reasoning. If a positive can be taken from this year’s shark incidents, it will be to reverse some assumptions and restore respect for the ocean. It’s not our swimming pool. It was never ours to take away.

Advertisement

There has been an alarming, and frankly astonishing, divergence between Australians’ use of the ocean and their respect for its risks. A March 2025 study by Royal Surf Lifesaving Australia found that among year 6 students, nearly half cannot swim 50 metres and tread water for two minutes. Only one in six 17-year-olds can swim the national benchmark distance of 400 metres. Swimming lessons in schools are in decline, a quarter of schools have no swimming carnivals, and Australians’ swimming ability shows “little improvement” after year 7. Each of these indicators had worsened since the COVID-19 pandemic, and yet the public, of all ages, is gravitating to the beach more and more. Irrational fear of sharks, as characterised in Jaws fictional Amity Island, is no better than irrational entitlement when it comes to how we interact with the ocean. Universal Pictures Notwithstanding efforts to educate people on swimming in rips, particularly from Rob “Dr Rip” Brander, there were 357 drowning deaths in Australia last year according to the National Drowning Report, 84 of them at beaches, a 27 per cent rise on the 10-year average. Shark incidents are different, of course, but they also involve assessing risk. Calls for improved education are thrown into sharp relief by the incident at North Steyne. I was there that day. The waves were ordinary but, Manly being Manly, in normal late-afternoon conditions there would have been dozens of surfers out. Days of rain had left murky water, so there were only three surfers on the entire stretch. The rest had weighed up the chance of an infection, and the two other shark incidents, and decided not to surf. Possibly de Ruyter and the two others saw a rare chance for empty North Steyne waves. They measured the odds. The chance of a shark incident was minuscule, if well above the normal. De Ruyter was incredibly unlucky – and also incredibly lucky that the two others were there to pull him from the water. These complex calculations of risk can be inbuilt through years of experience and grounded in respect for nature. But they’re still new in the scale of things. It’s easy to forget how recently the coastal ocean has come into non-Indigenous use. For colonial Australians, beach swimming began only a century ago and escalated to mass popularity in the last 50 years. In a blink, society has escalated the ocean environment from something unknown to a feature of cultural identity as Australian as the quarter-acre block. Irrational fear to reckless overconfidence in two generations.

Advertisement

The high prevalence of beach drownings among inexperienced swimmers underscores how long it takes to even begin to understand the ocean. Education of this kind is not a one-day course; it’s a lifelong accumulation of knowledge, of trial and error. Related Article Opinion

Sharks Surfers like me can’t get spooked by sharks. Then the fear wins Luke Kennedy Surfer and writer If there is one hope to take from the sad sight of this January’s empty beaches, it’s that respect for the ocean must be rebuilt. Not fear. Fear is not going in above the ankles one day, then diving straight into a rip the next. Respect, on the other hand, is a matter of acquiring skills, calculating probabilities, figuring out when the odds are with you and when they are against you, learning from experience, and above all not taking the ocean for granted as if it’s your personal playground. Being in the ocean is always a game of odds. Learning how to swim, learning rips and learning about sharky conditions are not guarantees of safety; they’re only ways of tilting the odds in your favour. The decline in swimming education, coinciding with an increase in beach use, is a snapshot of irrational entitlement. Its flipside is irrational fear, Amity Island in Jaws. Fatalities on our beaches shouldn’t terrify us; they should make us more humble in our approach to the ocean, more respectful, and more willing to learn. If absorbed in this way, the grim misfortunes of the past months can leave a positive legacy. Malcolm Knox is a journalist, author and columnist for The Sydney Morning Herald.

King Frederik and Queen Mary of Denmark are heading to Australia for a six-day state visit.

The couple, who met at the Sydney Olympics and married in 2004, will make their fourth official visit to Australia in March - their first since the King took the throne in 2024 following the abdication of his mother, Queen Margrethe II.

The royals will travel from the Northern Territory through the ACT, Victoria and Tasmania, where the queen was born and raised.

Loading

The couple will be accompanied by Denmark’s deputy prime minister, foreign minister and climate minister and a delegation representing 55 Danish businesses.

title: Prodigal guns: How the Waratahs harnessed hunger of stars they previously brushed
text:
Fast-forward to 2025, and Fainga’a found himself re-considering his earlier position. After a five-season stint with the Brumbies and a year in Perth, Fainga’a had moved to France to play for Clermont. With a year left on his contract, the coach who gave him a debut at the Brumbies - Dan McKellar - was on the phone asking if he’d come home to play for the Waratahs. Dave Porecki had retired, opening up a spot. The bitterness had receded, and with the chance to not only play under McKellar again, but re-ignite his Test career before the 2027 Rugby World Cup, Fainga’a accepted. A decade late, Fainga’a is a Waratah, and he is stoked. The 30-year-old will run out for NSW against the Reds in a trial at Ballymore on Saturday, and in a few weeks, make a Super Rugby debut for NSW as well. Fainga’a’s back-to-blue story is not an isolated one, either. The Waratahs squad in 2026 is littered with outstanding players who have been recruited back to their home state this season after initially being overlooked by the Tahs.

New captain Matt Philip, a former NSW under-20s skipper, had to move to Perth to debut and become a Wallaby. Pete Samu starred for Randwick and trialled with the Tahs in 2014, but left for New Zealand after missing a contract. Jack Debreczeni left for the Rebels in 2013, and Wallabies winger Harry Potter departed for Melbourne and then Leicester. All are back in Sydney with distinguished CVs and set to make Waratahs debuts next month. Matt Philip will lead the Waratahs in 2026. Credit: Peter Rae Like Fainga’a, the past has been forgiven but not forgotten, given how much it shaped them as players. Unlike many Waratahs in the past who were recruited as first-pick junior talent and didn’t fulfil their potential via the armchair route, the prodigal sons of 2026 were instilled with the hunger that comes from rejection. “I’ve always played with a little bit of a chip on my shoulder because of that, if I’m honest,” Philip said.

“That was obviously a very strong Waratahs team back in 2013-14, they won the comp. A part of me, definitely at the time, I was super frustrated, I would have loved to play in it. “But I think I wouldn’t be where I am today without that kind of setback. It’s made me hungry my whole career. I always wanted to prove them wrong, not making it that early in my career and having to go about things the hard way. Pete Samu left NSW and joined the Crusaders before becoming a Wallaby. Credit: Getty “But I’m also really grateful to be here. I can see how lucky we are to be playing for the NSW Waratahs. This is the home of rugby in Australia.” Samu was a rising star out of Melbourne who moved to Sydney in the hope of cracking the Waratahs, and was on the cusp after dominant seasons for Randwick in 2012 and 2013.

“That was definitely the aim,” Samu said. “I was lucky enough that I was part of the academy. “I got asked to do a pre-season with the Tahs - Cheik was the coach - and I played a couple of pre-season games as well. It was 2014, the start of that year. I was fighting for the last contract spot, which went to Ben Volavola at the time. But yeah, it’s pretty cool to have this full circle moment.” Samu’s next steps were good ones - he made his debut for the Crusaders - before Cheika righted his wrong and recruited him back to Australia to play for the Brumbies and the Wallabies. Debreczeni played NSW Schools and was also in the academy, which was national but based at the Waratahs. The big-kicking No.10 also had to leave Sydney to get a start at the Rebels, and 13 years and seven clubs later, also accepted an offer from McKellar for a belated run in blue.

“To see a lot of other blokes come back home, and who are keen to put on that blue jersey and represent their state, yeah, it gives good vibes around the group,” Fainga’a said. Loading Though a successful former Brumbies coach, McKellar has been at pains to say since taking over the Tahs last year that he doesn’t want to transplant the Canberra club’s style and culture. But there are definitely signs of some Brumbies’ DNA being spliced in. The Brumbies built their identity on being the discards of NSW, and the hunger that came with it. McKellar has strategically sought to repatriate lost Tahs - many of them from the Brumbies. He also signed Warringah’s Test flanker Luke Reimer for next year, too. “We want to be a club, an organisation - there’s no shortage of talent in New South Wales - where we retain and develop our best young players,” McKellar said.
